BLUE JAYS WILL FACE OLD LINERS AT STADIUM
TOMORROW IN ANNUAL GAME
Season Closes Following Biggest Clash of Year; Van Orman to
Spring Surprise Attack to End Season Successfully
The curtain will come down on the 1924 football season at Johns
Hopkins after the Maryland game. Whether it will be a success or
failure depends on tomorrow's result. Although the Blue Jays have
lost only to the strong Pittsburgh team this year their season cannot
be crowned with glory unless Maryland is subdued.
Maryland is equally as determined to carry off the laurels at the
Stadium tomorrow. They were taught a lesson last year, when the
game appeared so one-sided on paper only to have the battle of their
life to stave off defeat. The Old Liners' desires to turn the tables
has caused the contest to be the goal of Maryland's grid season.
In short, the success or failure

Those who attended the Assembly last Thursday mentally
enjoyed a trip to Sparrows Point
conducted by Mr. W..Frank Roberts, with the help of numerous
lantern slides. Mr. Roberts is the
General Manager of the Sparrows
Point plant of the Bethlehem
Steel Company and as Dean
Whitehead said upon presenting
him, he is familiar with every detail of the , methods employed in
the manufacture of iron and steel.

Let me state at the start that
the scenery, settings, and lighting
effects of the Playshop's production of Lord Dunsany's "If" were
good, were very good, in short
were excellent. Here, but for a
few exceptions, the merit of the
performance ended; the rest was
more or less rotten, to use a mild
HE finest materials, expert deadjective.
signing and careful workmanship
In the first place the play was
make every Stetson a masterpiece.
poor. Some months ago I read
one of Dunsany's one-act plays,
which gave me the idea that he
was a playwright of more than
average ability; I believe still in
my former view, but I likewise
believe that "If" is one of the
worst plays ever put on paper. It
is a sort of combination of Avery
Hopwood and Anne Nichols, with
Anne handling the English scenes,
and Avery the Persian. With a
We Solicit Your Patronage
little more freedom in the costuming the piece would have made an
excellent bedroom drama; that is
the third and fourth acts would.
Perhaps I am putting it a little

the "Man in the corner"; but the
rest—oh, never mind the rest.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 26, 1924

THE GAME
There is only one thing to write about today. To attempt to fill
this column with a long treatise on some deep scholastic problem
would be senseless, with the Maryland game tomorrow at the Stadium. And though what we say about it may have been already said
and thought by everyone interested in the encounter, we think it
still should be put down here, simply as a reminder of the traditional
battle for State Championship.

CXeHLITZLER

BOOKSHOP
Invites You to Call

There are many sport fans in the City of Baltimore who will not
concede Johns Hopkins a chance to win tomorrow's game. We make
no predictions. We realize the type of team that Coach Byrd of
Maryland produces. We realize that the Maryland team and the
Maryland supporters are primed for this contest. But, Hopkins'
tradition of fighting football teams has been continued this year. The
Hopkins.squad has performed magnificently, displaying courage and
determination which thrills every onlooker. We recall the knowledge
of the fundamentals and the uncanny alertness which has made the
Hopkins team famous for "following the ball" and taking advantage
of the breaks. -We recall the airtight defense which prevented Maryland last year from gaining victory. We recall the 6 6 score against
a heavier team which was conceded the odds in every department
of the game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, NOVEMBER 26, 1924

$3,000,000 EYE INSTITUTE PLANNED
WITH DR. W. H. WILMER LIKELY HEAD

Ernest G. Leimbach
2819 Greenmount Avenue

Continued from page 1

century.
"The result is that the American public does not receive such
skilled attention in the treatment of
diseases of the eye as would be possible if there were a first rank institution for the training of ophthalmologists in this country.
'"The movement to found such an
institute began among the friends
and patients of Dr. Wilmer. Several years ago they incorporated
the Wilmer Foundation for the
purpose of raising a fund to be used
in any manner which might result
in enlarging the usefulness of his
work. When the trustees of the
foundation discovered that an institute of ophthalmology was contemplated as a part of the present tenyear program of •the Johns Hopkins University and the Johns Hopkins Hospital, they decided that
their purpose, as well as ours, might
best be served through the integration of both plans."

Dr. Goodnow said that it would
cost approximately $1,000,000 to
erect and equip the proposed Wilmer Institute. The plan also calls
for $1,000,000 to endow at least
forty free beds and provide income
for the treatment of patients who
have not the means to pay the full
cost of hospital care. A third $1,000,000 will be required to endow
the teaching of ophthalmology in
the medical school and to pay the
salaries of the institute's staff, who
will also be officers of the Johns
Hopkins Hospital and members of
the medical faculty.
Dr. Wilmer, according to the
present plan, will become Professor of Ophthalmology in the Medical School and Ophthalmologist of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The Wilmer Foundation already
has $200,000 to contribute to the
project, but under the present tentative arrangement the entire $3,000,000, or a large part of it, must
be raised before January 1, 1925.

A. Bruce Bielaski, a graduate of

President of Delta Tau Delta, is

The representative of the Interfraternity Council of the Johns
Hopkins University is Bayard P.
Fonda.

Dr. Wilmer a Virginian

Dr. Wilmer was born in Powhatan County, Virginia, in 1863.
He was graduated from the medical school of the University of Virginia. in 1885. and afterwards studied in the Polyclinic Hospital, New
York, and in various European hospitals. He began the practice of
medicine in Washington, D. C., in
1889, and for many years was proin
Ophthalmology
fessor
of
Georgetown University.
D.uring the war he was officer in
charge of the Medical Research
Laboratory of the Air Service at
Mineola, L. I., and was later surgeon in charge of the Medical Research Laboratories of the A. E. F.
He is a member of the advisory
board of'.directory of the National
Committee for the Prevention of
Blindness and holds positions of
like importance in many other similar organizations.
His publications, particularly in regard to glaucoma, one of the common causes of
blindness among adults, have been
regarded as most important contributions in advancing methods for
treatment of diseases of the eye.

Class dues for 1924-25 were.announced by the treasurer. Each
senior will be assessed twentyfive dollars, of which eighteen
dollars vill be used for the Hullabaloo, five dollars for June Week,
and the remaining two dollars for
incidental expenses.
President Calhoun brought to
the attention of the class a plan
for a $25,000 endowmeiit policy.
The scheme, suggested to him by
local insurance men, was to take
out $1,000 policies on twenty-five
members of the class, and pay for
this in yearly installments. At
the end of a certain time the money will be used as a gift to the

His Patients Prominent

Dr. Wilmer's patients have included many of the foremost persons of America. The trustees of
the Wilmer Foundation are: Robert W. Kelley, president; Henry
Breckinridge, secretary-treasurer;
Mrs. Aida de Acosta Root, Robert
M. Thompson, William P. Eno, Joseph Pulitzer, Mrs. Henry R. Rea,
Mrs. Douglas Robinson, Felix
Warburg, Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., Major General Merritt \V.
Ireland, Mrs. William Ross Proctor, Herbert L. Satterlee and Harold F. Pierce.

IMPORTANT BUSINESS AT University from the class of 1925.
SENIOR CLASS MEETING
Action on the matter was post-

Fifty-seven Seniors were present in the M. E. Hall on November 17, when nominations for Student Council were reopened. Previously, Post and Fringer had
been nominated for the position,
but it was contended that most of
the class was absent at the time.
When the motion to reopen the
lists was made a heated discussion
ensued, but the motion was finally
222 & 224 W_ Baltimore St.
carried by a vote of twenty-nine
tammtamtcmc= to twenty-eight. A. L. Gump was
then nominated and placed on the
ballot along with Fringer and
Post
The election will take
place on Wednesday, November
26.

SHERWOOD BROTHERS, INC.

As yet the trustees of the Johns
Hopkins University and the Johns
Hopkins Hospital have not taken
.inal action on the project but this
will not delay the plans for finaning it.

he said that Seniors will be expected to sell two books of tickets
instead of one, in order to compensate for those not sold by underclassmen.

W. F. ROBERTS ADDRESSES
ASSEMBLY ON STEEL
Continued from page 1

ern processes of manufacture.
The crucible process, he said, has
proved unsatisfactory i recent
years. Bessemer's method of
forcing air through molten pigiron in a giant converter is much
more simple and convenient. In
communities where electric power is cheap, the electric arc furnace is used, which has a capacity
of about 30 tons. The openhearth process, however, is generally accepted as better than any
other in the manufacturing of
steel on a large scale. Pig-iron
is placed in an open furnace and
subjected to a tremendously high
temperature, as high as the brick
work can stand, for eight or
twelve hours. 250 tons of molten
steel is the result. Most of the
steel manufactured in the world
today is open hearth steel.
A number of illustrative slides
were thrown on the screen showing pictures .of the extensive steel
works at Sparrows Point. These
included the rolling mills, with
their vast system of complicated
rollers capable of reducing huge
ingots of red-hot steel to thin
strips or plates; the huge blast
furnace; the insatiable Bessemer
converters with bursts of flame
roaring out of their upturned
mouths; the orderly rows of coke
ovens-; and many other interesting
pictures of the mighty machinery
used in the iron and steel industry.
Mr. Roberts concluded his talk
with the statement that, although
there has been a great deal of
speculation as to the suppiy 01
iron ore in the world, it has been
estimated that only seven percent of the reserve of ore has been
used in the history of iron.
After George Hess announced
that notices would be posted some
time this week advising Seniors
where the Hullabaloo pictures
will be taken, Townsend rolled*
up the slide screen disclosing on
the blackboard two magic words:
"Beat Maryland !" The noise
that ensued must have convinced
anyone within the radius of a mile
that Hopkins is in dead earnest
about backing up the team on
Thanksgiving Day. There will
be a giant bonfire to prove it.

He—Do you think that you
could learn to love me?
She—I'm afraid not.
He—'Tis as I feared, too old to
learn.—Jack o' Lantern.

Across Another Man's Desk
Those looking forward to careers in
business often associate the big accomplishments with men in private offices, who sit
back of massive desks. As a matter offact,
there are many important men in an organization like Westinghouse who seldom use
a desk or office at all. They achieve by
going to other men's offices. They are termed
"sales engineers".

be witnessed in every branch of industrial
life today.

George Westinghouse,for example,rendered his greatest service to industry and
mankind not merely by perfecting alternating current but by selling it—in the face
of the stiffest kind of opposition.

Following the example of its Founder,
the Westinghouse organization includes a
body of engineers whose work is to carry
electrical advancement into every nook and
corner of the world. They have sold electrification to the factories, the farms, the
homes, the railroads, the mines, the ships.
They are mechanical and electrical, engineers whose imaginations are fired, not
merely by engineering achievement, but
by the benefits from such achievement to
"the market".

Authorities declared it was impractical; laws were urged against it; yet the
salesman, Westinghouse, threw back of
alternating current, the strength of his
selling personality—with results that can

Engineering needs men of sales ability
and sales personality; and industry needs
to have them in engineering. Organizations like Westinghouse, must sell before
they can serve.

Westinghouse

BLUE JAYS WILL FACE OLD LINERS AT STADIUM
TOMORROW IN ANNUAL GAME
Season Closes Following Biggest Clash of Year; Van Orman to
Spring Surprise Attack to End Season Successfully
The curtain will come down on the 1924 football season at Johns
Hopkins after the Maryland game. Whether it will be a success or
failure depends on tomorrow's result. Although the Blue Jays have
lost only to the strong Pittsburgh team this year their season cannot
be crowned with glory unless Maryland is subdued.
Maryland is equally as determined to carry off the laurels at the
Stadium tomorrow. They were taught a lesson last year, when the
game appeared so one-sided on paper only to have the battle of their
life to stave off defeat. The Old Liners' desires to turn the tables
has caused the contest to be the goal of Maryland's grid season.
In short, the success or failure

conducted by Mr. W..Frank Roberts, with the help of numerous

Point plant of the Bethlehem
Steel Company and as Dean
Whitehead said upon presenting
him, he is familiar with every detail of the , methods employed in
the manufacture of iron and steel.

Let me state at the start that
the scenery, settings, and lighting
effects of the Playshop's production of Lord Dunsany's "If" were

were excellent. Here, but for a
few exceptions, the merit of the
performance ended; the rest was
more or less rotten, to use a mild
HE finest materials, expert deadjective.

make every Stetson a masterpiece.
poor. Some months ago I read
one of Dunsany's one-act plays,
which gave me the idea that he
was a playwright of more than
average ability; I believe still in
my former view, but I likewise
believe that "If" is one of the
worst plays ever put on paper. It
is a sort of combination of Avery
Hopwood and Anne Nichols, with
Anne handling the English scenes,
and Avery the Persian. With a

little more freedom in the costuming the piece would have made an

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 26, 1924

THE GAME
There is only one thing to write about today. To attempt to fill
this column with a long treatise on some deep scholastic problem
would be senseless, with the Maryland game tomorrow at the Stadium. And though what we say about it may have been already said
and thought by everyone interested in the encounter, we think it
still should be put down here, simply as a reminder of the traditional
battle for State Championship.

CXeHLITZLER

BOOKSHOP
Invites You to Call

There are many sport fans in the City of Baltimore who will not
concede Johns Hopkins a chance to win tomorrow's game. We make
no predictions. We realize the type of team that Coach Byrd of
Maryland produces. We realize that the Maryland team and the
Maryland supporters are primed for this contest. But, Hopkins'
tradition of fighting football teams has been continued this year. The
Hopkins.squad has performed magnificently, displaying courage and
determination which thrills every onlooker. We recall the knowledge
of the fundamentals and the uncanny alertness which has made the
Hopkins team famous for "following the ball" and taking advantage
of the breaks. -We recall the airtight defense which prevented Maryland last year from gaining victory. We recall the 6 6 score against
a heavier team which was conceded the odds in every department
of the game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, NOVEMBER 26, 1924

$3,000,000 EYE INSTITUTE PLANNED
WITH DR. W. H. WILMER LIKELY HEAD

Ernest G. Leimbach
2819 Greenmount Avenue

Continued from page 1

century.
"The result is that the American public does not receive such
skilled attention in the treatment of
diseases of the eye as would be possible if there were a first rank institution for the training of ophthalmologists in this country.
'"The movement to found such an
institute began among the friends
and patients of Dr. Wilmer. Several years ago they incorporated
the Wilmer Foundation for the
purpose of raising a fund to be used
in any manner which might result
in enlarging the usefulness of his
work. When the trustees of the
foundation discovered that an institute of ophthalmology was contemplated as a part of the present tenyear program of •the Johns Hopkins University and the Johns Hopkins Hospital, they decided that
their purpose, as well as ours, might
best be served through the integration of both plans."

Dr. Goodnow said that it would
cost approximately $1,000,000 to
erect and equip the proposed Wilmer Institute. The plan also calls
for $1,000,000 to endow at least
forty free beds and provide income
for the treatment of patients who
have not the means to pay the full
cost of hospital care. A third $1,000,000 will be required to endow
the teaching of ophthalmology in
the medical school and to pay the
salaries of the institute's staff, who
will also be officers of the Johns
Hopkins Hospital and members of
the medical faculty.
Dr. Wilmer, according to the
present plan, will become Professor of Ophthalmology in the Medical School and Ophthalmologist of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The Wilmer Foundation already
has $200,000 to contribute to the
project, but under the present tentative arrangement the entire $3,000,000, or a large part of it, must
be raised before January 1, 1925.

Dr. Wilmer a Virginian

Dr. Wilmer was born in Powhatan County, Virginia, in 1863.
He was graduated from the medical school of the University of Virginia. in 1885. and afterwards studied in the Polyclinic Hospital, New
York, and in various European hospitals. He began the practice of
medicine in Washington, D. C., in
1889, and for many years was proin
Ophthalmology
fessor
of
Georgetown University.
D.uring the war he was officer in
charge of the Medical Research
Laboratory of the Air Service at
Mineola, L. I., and was later surgeon in charge of the Medical Research Laboratories of the A. E. F.
He is a member of the advisory
board of'.directory of the National
Committee for the Prevention of
Blindness and holds positions of
like importance in many other similar organizations.
His publications, particularly in regard to glaucoma, one of the common causes of
blindness among adults, have been
regarded as most important contributions in advancing methods for
treatment of diseases of the eye.

IMPORTANT BUSINESS AT University from the class of 1925.
SENIOR CLASS MEETING
Action on the matter was post-

Fifty-seven Seniors were present in the M. E. Hall on November 17, when nominations for Student Council were reopened. Previously, Post and Fringer had
been nominated for the position,
but it was contended that most of
the class was absent at the time.
When the motion to reopen the
lists was made a heated discussion
ensued, but the motion was finally
222 & 224 W_ Baltimore St.
carried by a vote of twenty-nine
tammtamtcmc= to twenty-eight. A. L. Gump was
then nominated and placed on the
ballot along with Fringer and
Post
The election will take
place on Wednesday, November
26.

W. F. ROBERTS ADDRESSES
ASSEMBLY ON STEEL
Continued from page 1

ern processes of manufacture.
The crucible process, he said, has
proved unsatisfactory i recent
years. Bessemer's method of
forcing air through molten pigiron in a giant converter is much
more simple and convenient. In
communities where electric power is cheap, the electric arc furnace is used, which has a capacity
of about 30 tons. The openhearth process, however, is generally accepted as better than any
other in the manufacturing of
steel on a large scale. Pig-iron
is placed in an open furnace and
subjected to a tremendously high
temperature, as high as the brick
work can stand, for eight or
twelve hours. 250 tons of molten
steel is the result. Most of the
steel manufactured in the world
today is open hearth steel.
A number of illustrative slides
were thrown on the screen showing pictures .of the extensive steel
works at Sparrows Point. These
included the rolling mills, with
their vast system of complicated
rollers capable of reducing huge
ingots of red-hot steel to thin
strips or plates; the huge blast
furnace; the insatiable Bessemer
converters with bursts of flame
roaring out of their upturned
mouths; the orderly rows of coke
ovens-; and many other interesting
pictures of the mighty machinery
used in the iron and steel industry.
Mr. Roberts concluded his talk
with the statement that, although
there has been a great deal of
speculation as to the suppiy 01
iron ore in the world, it has been
estimated that only seven percent of the reserve of ore has been
used in the history of iron.
After George Hess announced
that notices would be posted some
time this week advising Seniors
where the Hullabaloo pictures
will be taken, Townsend rolled*
up the slide screen disclosing on
the blackboard two magic words:
"Beat Maryland !" The noise
that ensued must have convinced
anyone within the radius of a mile
that Hopkins is in dead earnest
about backing up the team on
Thanksgiving Day. There will
be a giant bonfire to prove it.

Across Another Man's Desk
Those looking forward to careers in
business often associate the big accomplishments with men in private offices, who sit
back of massive desks. As a matter offact,
there are many important men in an organization like Westinghouse who seldom use
a desk or office at all. They achieve by
going to other men's offices. They are termed
"sales engineers".

be witnessed in every branch of industrial
life today.

George Westinghouse,for example,rendered his greatest service to industry and
mankind not merely by perfecting alternating current but by selling it—in the face
of the stiffest kind of opposition.

Following the example of its Founder,
the Westinghouse organization includes a
body of engineers whose work is to carry
electrical advancement into every nook and
corner of the world. They have sold electrification to the factories, the farms, the
homes, the railroads, the mines, the ships.
They are mechanical and electrical, engineers whose imaginations are fired, not
merely by engineering achievement, but
by the benefits from such achievement to
"the market".

Authorities declared it was impractical; laws were urged against it; yet the
salesman, Westinghouse, threw back of
alternating current, the strength of his
selling personality—with results that can

Engineering needs men of sales ability
and sales personality; and industry needs
to have them in engineering. Organizations like Westinghouse, must sell before
they can serve.
